data.text:
Age 19 Years.

Loving son of Louis and Sophia Pitsch. Walter was employed as a machinist helper and was single.

Cause of Death: Pneumonia

"Walter Pitsch died Wednesday afternoon at the residence of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Pitsch, 436 South Thirteenth Street. Jan. 19, last, while at work in the Pere Marquette shops, he had his toe smashed. Other complications set in and hastened his death. He was at St. Mary's Hospital for four weeks receiving treatment, and two weeks ago he was removed to his home. He was conscious till the last, and had hopes of getting well up till the moment he passed away. He was born in this city Sept. 19, 1892, and attended the public schools here. He was confirmed in St. John's Evangelical Lutheran Church April 7, 1907, and was a favorite with his classmates. He is survived by his parents, two sisters and three brothers, Herman Pitsch; Mrs. Wm. A. Roggmann; Mrs. Ernest Elbert; Albert Krohn; and Wm. C. Krohn, all of this city; also his aged grandmother, Mrs. Wilhelmina Knopp, of Peotine, IL; besides numerous friends; and other relatives.

The funeral will take place Sunday afternoon at 1:45 o'clock from the residence, 436 South Thirteenth Street, and at 2:30 from St. John's Evangelical Lutheran Church. Rev. Frederick Volz will officiate, with interment in Forest Lawn Cemetery.

The funeral services were conducted by Rev. Frederick Volz, who paid a fitting tribute to the departed. The couch casket, as it rested in the parlor at the home, was nearly hidden from view by a wealth of flowers, which were offerings of sympathy, from a host of friends. Among the many pieces was a Gates Ajar from the Pere Marquette shopmates, a broken wheel from the machinist apprentices, a spray from the post office, E. S. clerks, a crescent from the neighbors. The machinists attended in a body. Interment was made in Forest Lawn Cemetery in a bed of evergreen. The following apprentices of the Pere Marquette shops acted as pallbearers, James Ried; Emil Koden; M. Heppler; Fred Baumer; Clarence Friend; and Frank Stork."

Source Saginaw Library, Saginaw News
